info.game_comments:
2014 Teen Tournament final game 2.
Last game of Season 30.

(1, 1).clue: Meaning "I approve", "coo" is short for this; saving 1 keystroke adds up

(2, 1).clue: Boulder, Colorado is in the Flatiron Range, part of these mountains

(3, 1).clue: It's said that "it takes two to" do this dance that evolved in Buenos Aires

(5, 1).clue: "A Journey" (maybe a short one on a speed skating track)

(6, 1).clue: "Jaws", about one of these sea creatures, kept lots of folks out of the water

(1, 2).clue: "GTG" can mean "good to go" or this parting phrase

(2, 2).clue: What the Arabs call Jebel Musa, "Mountain of Moses", is better known as this

(3, 2).clue: This dance that was popular in the 1920s is named for a city in South Carolina

(4, 2).clue: A mineral deposite from which metal can be extracted

(6, 2).clue: You can see this monster from Egypt's past in a film from back in 1932 or at Universal Studios

(1, 3).clue: Someone who types "sup" to you is contracting these 2 words

(2, 3).clue: You must be 42" tall to hop on this Disneyland ride; its 14,692-foot namesake in the pennine alps is tougher sledding

(3, 3).clue: A pair of quick steps are followed by a pair of slow ones in the dance called the Texas this

(4, 3).clue: Hold your horses & give me this synonym for sadness

(1, 4).clue: In "kk", the first K replaces this letter

(2, 4).clue: This peak is the only mountain in North America that exceeds 20,000 feet

(3, 4).clue: Dances with repetitive names include the cancan & this lively Cuban dance

(4, 4).clue: In a fairy tale, a princess can feel it through 20 mattresses

(6, 4).clue: This lovestruck giant ape ends up far from skull island, his home

(1, 5).clue: Writer Adam Gopnik was among parents who made their kids snicker by thinking "LOL" meant this, not "laugh out loud"

(2, 5).clue: Not quite 14,500 feet, this California peak is named for geologist Josiah

(3, 5).clue: Polite society was shocked to see couples in close contact for this ballroom dance that has a Viennese type

(4, 5).clue: The last class of the day seems to last this long, the longest division of geologic time

(5, 5).clue: An electrical genius from Europe: "My Inventions"

(6, 5).clue: Abe Sapein helps this well-"red" guy went from the dark side to working for our side

(1, 1).clue: He's the President seen here signing into law the Civil Rights Act of 1964

(2, 1).clue: December is a good time to see this 1892 ballet that features the Sugar Plum Fairy

(3, 1).clue: One symptom of love is a loss of this, the desire for food

(4, 1).clue: Lewis Morgan said we've progressed "from savagery through barbarism to" this sophisticated stage

(5, 1).clue: Incorporating part of an old song into a new song, or trying a free piece of cheese at the deli

(6, 1).clue: For very low temperatures, these may use magnets instead of mercury

(1, 2).clue: In the early '80s, it was sometimes called "GRID", gay-related immune deficiency

(2, 2).clue: Praise the Lord! Over a century old, this American form of Christian music combines elements of blues, jazz & spirituals

(3, 2).clue: Xerostomia means a dry one of these; try not to put your foot in yours when you talk to your crush

(4, 2).clue: "Bougie", slang for upscale or snobby, comes from this class described by Karl Marx

(5, 2).clue: If your iPod display reads "Drake f/ Majid Jordan", the f/ stands for this

(6, 2).clue: Name of a city in southern Colorado as well as Tobago's partner island

(1, 3).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew shows a map on the monitor.)  On the morning of June 25th, 1950, forces in the north stormed across the 38th parallel, beginning this 3-year long conflict

(2, 3).clue: Donatello sculpted a marble statue of this biblical youth almost 100 years before Michelangelo

(3, 3).clue: When your beloved is near, you hear the 1824 "Ode to Joy" by this composer

(4, 3).clue: Elsie Parsons studied these "apartment" dwelling Indians of the Southwest, including the Zuni

(5, 3).clue: An album that sells 10 million copies is certified this gem

(6, 3).clue: Look out, this type of small family store, here comes Walmart

(1, 4).clue: This senator from Wisconsin is best remembered for his Communist "witch hunts" of the 1950s

(2, 4).clue: This city's pops is affectionately known as "America's Orchestra"

(3, 4).clue: Poor coordination & tingling--could be love or a lack of thiamine, also called this alphanumeric vitamin

(4, 4).clue: A classic work of cultural anthropology is antonymically titled this "and the cooked"

(5, 4).clue: "AC" stands for this radio format favored by some folks of a certain age

(6, 4).clue: A relaxing type of herbal tea from celestial seasonings

(1, 5).clue: In 1972, terrorism by a group of Palestinians marred the Olympic Games in this German city

(2, 5).clue: At the Louvre, 16th century Italian tapestries depict scenes from this poet's "Metamorphoses"

(3, 5).clue: Forms of this abnormality of the heartbeat include "skipping a beat", fibrillation & tachycardia, beating too fast

(4, 5).clue: In 1925 she set out for the South Pacific to study adolescent girls

(5, 5).clue: A songwriter can make money writing these; they are brief catchy tunes to sell cars, tissues or prunes

(6, 5).clue: Meaning "city", this word comes before "Juarez" & "de Mexico"

(0, 0).clue: There were no winners for this award from 1939 through 1943; in 1944, it was won by the International Committee of the Red Cross
